title: Jesus' Triumphal Entry and Teachings
shortSummary: Matthew 21 recounts Jesus' triumphant entry into Jerusalem, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy and asserting His messianic authority. The chapter also includes Jesus cleansing the temple, teaching through parables, and emphasizing faith, obedience, and the coming judgment on unfruitfulness.
timeline: c. AD 30 - The final week before Jesus' crucifixion

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Messiah and Son of David who enters Jerusalem, cleanses the temple, teaches parables, and reveals His authority.

keyCharacters.name: Disciples
keyCharacters.description: Followers of Jesus who carry out His instructions, witness His miracles, and learn from His teachings.

keyCharacters.name: Chief Priests and Elders
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who challenge Jesus' authority and reject His message, ultimately plotting against Him.

keyCharacters.name: Publicans and Harlots
keyCharacters.description: Social outcasts who respond in faith to John the Baptist and Jesus’ message, contrasted with the religious leaders’ unbelief.

definitions.definition: A Hebrew expression meaning 'Save now' or 'Please save,' used as a shout of praise and recognition of Jesus as Messiah.
A donkey and its young, symbolizing humility and peace; Jesus riding them fulfills Zechariah’s prophecy about the Messiah’s peaceful entry.
A phrase Jesus uses to condemn the temple merchants for turning God's house into a place of greed and corruption.
A common biblical metaphor for Israel or God’s kingdom, often used to illustrate stewardship and judgment.
A Messianic reference from Psalm 118:22 symbolizing Jesus as the cornerstone rejected by religious leaders but foundational for salvation.

outline.heading: The Triumphal Entry into Jerusalem
outline.description: Jesus instructs His disciples to bring a donkey and colt, fulfilling prophecy as He enters Jerusalem humbly yet royally, greeted by crowds shouting 'Hosanna.' This event publicly declares Jesus as the promised King.

outline.heading: Cleansing of the Temple and Healing
outline.description: Jesus drives out the moneychangers and merchants, condemning their corruption in the temple, and heals the blind and lame, demonstrating His authority and compassion.

outline.heading: The Withering of the Fig Tree and Teaching on Faith
outline.description: Jesus curses a barren fig tree as a symbol of judgment on unfruitfulness, teaching His disciples about the power of faith and prayer without doubt.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Authority Questioned
outline.description: Religious leaders challenge Jesus’ authority, but He exposes their unwillingness to acknowledge John the Baptist’s divine mission, leaving them unable to answer.

outline.heading: Parables on Obedience and Judgment
outline.description: Jesus teaches two parables: the two sons and the wicked husbandmen, illustrating true obedience, repentance, rejection of the Messiah, and the transfer of God’s kingdom to faithful believers.

application: Approach Jesus with humility and faith, recognizing Him as King and Savior in all areas of life.
Maintain a heart of obedience and repentance rather than mere lip service, following Jesus’ example and teachings.
Exercise faith in prayer, trusting God’s power to accomplish what seems impossible.
Guard against spiritual complacency and hypocrisy by bearing fruit consistent with true faith.

keyVerses.text: And the multitudes that went before, and that followed, cried, saying, Hosanna to the Son of David: Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord; Hosanna in the highest.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the public recognition of Jesus as the Messiah and King, fulfilling prophecy and setting the stage for His final week.

keyVerses.text: And said unto them, It is written, My house shall be called the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus condemns the corruption in the temple, emphasizing the sanctity of worship and God’s righteous judgment on sin.

keyVerses.text: Jesus answered and said unto them, Verily I say unto you, If ye have faith, and doubt not, ye shall not only do this which is done to the fig tree, but also if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; it shall be done.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the power of unwavering faith in God to accomplish extraordinary things.

keyVerses.text: Therefore say I unto you, The kingdom of God shall be taken from you, and given to a nation bringing forth the fruits thereof.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus warns that God’s kingdom requires genuine fruitfulness and obedience, and rejection leads to judgment and transfer of blessing.
